column3: I've never been a great one for technology.

Regardless of what the naysayers believe about human interaction and social media, the data show us that the abundance of technology is actually increasing the abundance of happiness all over the world.

Why should Congresspeople have to visit D.C.? Thanks to Skype, meetings are possible across the country. Thanks to email, communications are simple. And we've had the technology to vote from afar for decades. Why should we have backroom deals made over cigars thousands of miles distant from those who are affected by those deals?
I love technology. We can be our own DJs wherever we go.
The Amish communities of Pennsylvania, despite the retro image of horse-drawn buggies and straw hats, have long been engaged in a productive debate about the consequences of technology.
You used to have to sing and convey emotion, and now, well, technically you can do anything with technology. It sucks for music today, but that's why that old music feels so good to me.
As technology continues to increase our possibilities, what we're seeing is a shrinking of the lag time between what we dream about and what we create.

For a lot of people, one of the reasons they don't like to work for founders of startups is that they can be sensitive and protective around what they've built. You have an emotional attachment to the early marketing and technology materials, and you don't want to hear that anything's wrong with them.

Of course, technology is not an exogenous force over which humans have no control. We are not constrained by a binary choice between acceptance and rejection. Rather, the decisions we make every day as citizens, consumers, and investors guide technological progress.
The world is very different now. For man holds in his mortal hands the power to abolish all forms of human poverty, and all forms of human life.
Sites need to be able to interact in one single, universal space.
We're still in the first minutes of the first day of the Internet revolution.

These days the technology can solve our problems and then some. Solutions may not only erase physical or mental deficits but leave patients better off than 'able-bodied' folks. The person who has a disability today may have a superability tomorrow.
Banking technology has made it simple and efficient to invest in good causes.

What we are witnessing is the birth of something I call 'Polisdigitocracy.' This is a form of government that counts participation and transparency as its cornerstones and uses technology as its guide. The digital revolution is allowing democracy to recall its foundations and evolution is modernizing and reinforcing our fundamental values.
Many of the engineers I interviewed worked on reverse-engineering technology. It's a hallmark of Area 51.
My graduate studies were carried out at the California Institute of Technology.
India is at the vanguard of figuring out how to exploit technology and innovation on behalf of democratic accountability.
I'm one of the people who was a pioneer in encouraging musicians, early in the game, to get interested in technology, and now all the musicians are getting into it.
With any advent in technology, any technological innovation, there is the good and the bad.
If GM had kept up with technology like the computer industry has, we would all be driving $25 cars that got 1,000 MPG.
There is a difference between what technology enables and what historical business practices enable.
Digital technology has several features that can make it much easier for teachers to pay special attention to all their students.
Software substitution, whether it's for drivers or waiters or nurses - it's progressing. Technology over time will reduce demand for jobs, particularly at the lower end of skill set.
Technology is unlocking the innate compassion we have for our fellow human beings.
Science, as opposed to technology, does violence to common sense.
